content: I have recently been congratulating a new user on the italian board for his astonishing Merit/Post ratio. This particular user is a well known expert user in the italian community, and already provided good content here on the forum, where heâ€™s new. So this ratio is quite expected. As heâ€™s pretty new to the forum, he asked me â€œwhat is a great merit/post ratio?. This is something it resonated with me, as he very first thread I opened here on the forum was on a very similar subject: Quote from: fillippone on June 27, 2018, 10:58:12 PMHello,I am quite new to this board, so I am trying to provide the best post I could as I find the merit system a good way to raise the signal/noise ratio.I accidentally bumped in a user with over 1k posts and almost the same merit.Is there a way to have a ranking of best user sorted with high ratio?Time is even scarcer than bitcoin, so I want to effectively use my time to learn from user that posted quality stuff using effectively their time!Thanks,F1I think the idea ha some value, so I decided to leverage @ddmrddmr merit dashboard and try to figure out something.Bitcointalk Merit DashboardI did the following steps: downloaded the entire forum population from @ddmrddmr dashboard from the User Summary Tabfiltered out banned usersfiltered out "brand new" members computed the ratio between received merits and setup other filters on post, merits and ratiosorted the users according to descending Received Merit/Post ratioThe following table is the outputIf you click on the above graph you will be redirected to the interactive If you are wondering who those outliers are, have a look at the TOP 50 (excuse me for my poor formatting capabilities):Pos User IDPostsReceived Merits/PostsForum ProfileBPIPNinjastic.space1. bitcoinchan135(Forum Profile)(BPIP)(Ninjastic.space)2. comments.author: Timelord2067
comments.body: Interesting post.Â  Statistics can be skewered in any direction.Â  You might want to go back and filter out the shower of merits to and from merit sources who have their favourites they snow ball merits in closed circles.Â  Plus, you might want to remove some of the super threads where the users just endlessly merit each-others posts even though they have no substance.

comments.author: DdmrDdmr
comments.body: When I used to do analysis rather frequently back in the day, I looked at the Merit per post ratio, and one of the difficulties in compiling or interpreting the data is the fact that quite a few accounts had many posts created before the introduction of the Merit System, which normally would drag down their result (except for the likes ofÂ  Hal, Satoshi, Laszlo and so forth). Other less prominent long-standing accounts will have a lower ratio due to their pre-Merit System posting backlog, when comparted to accounts born into the Merit System.To a certain degree, an ideal criteria would more or less play around with the post count at the time the Merit System kicked-off, and device how to use that in the calculus (i.e. if an account is pre-Merit System, but posted mostly/largely after it kicked-off, consider the post count at the time the Merit System kicked-off, and not the total number of posts). Another interesting variation, subject to the same problematic as the one said above, is to calculate the percentage of merited posts, which gives a sense of broadness to the merit/post ratio. comments.author: joker_josue
comments.body: Quote from: fillippone on January 11, 2023, 04:02:23 PMI have recently been congratulating a new user on the italian board for his astonishing Merit/Post ratio. This particular user is a well known expert user in the italian community, and already provided good content here on the forum, where heâ€™s new. So this ratio is quite expected. As heâ€™s pretty new to the forum, he asked me â€œwhat is a great merit/post ratio?. First of all, congratulations for another analysis. It's always good to be able to see things from different perspectives, to have an idea of how things are evolving.Now, I think this type of relationship is very subjective and doesn't exactly mean that a user with little posts and many merits is better than others. Because a user who makes few quality posts and is not very active, who receives many deserved merits, will always have a better ratio than a user who makes quality topics and is very active (where logically not all participations deserve merit) will have a ratio lower.

comments.body: Quote from: fillippone on January 11, 2023, 04:02:23 PMsorted the users according to descending Received Merit/Post ratioI was also thinking if such statistics can be made. Good job, fillippone!Having more merits than posts may happen (in those cases named by 1miau as "hit and run", meaning a low ranking user which gets a ton of merits for one post then he leaves the forum) but keeping such a ratio on the long run is almost impossible. Furthermore, if even in "normal conditions" this is something hard to achieve, for those which created their accounts before merit system was implemented -- for these ones it's almost impossible.
